Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Low-Cost Portable Telerehabilitation System for Intelligent Stretching and Remote Assessment of Hypertonic Arm Joints
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase II research project seeks to develop technologies needed for rehabilitation of post-stroke patients with neurological impairment. For those patients, physical therapy followed by timely examination is the cornerstone of the rehabilitation. However, not all patients receive sufficient therapy due to limited access to expert healthcare services. There is a need for a tele-rehabilitation system that can stretch the spastic/contractured joints under accurate control at a remote location and provide remote access to expert healthcare services. This Phase II research will focus on improving the technology and making it suitable for the market by improving the design of the tele-rehabilitation system for multi-purpose applications to treat/evaluate multiple joints in the arm. It will make the portable device stand-alone with built-in capabilities of passive stretching, voluntary movement exercise, and tele-assessment of joint range of motion, stiffness, spasticity, and catch displayed in an intuitive way. Finally, a clinical test of the tele-rehabilitation system on stroke survivors will be conducted.

This portable and low-cost stretching device is suitable for home use, making frequent and convenient treatment accessible to a large number of patients. It can potentially have broad impact on rehabilitation of stroke and other neurological impairments. The intelligent stretching concept was developed to insure safe and effective treatment and it will also be useful in other applications dealing with human-machine interface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The target population of our project outcomes is stroke survivors. Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability and the third leading cause of death in the United States. Currently, stroke survivors require one-on-one manual treatment from the therapist and the expenditure of personalized physical therapy consumes 3–4% of the national health budget. For many post-stroke patients at home, the routine access to expert clinical assessment is severely limited by Medicare resource and distance to a qualified medical center, resulting in suboptimal treatment therapies or dosages. Physical therapy followed by timely examination is the cornerstone of the rehabilitation. However, not all patients receive sufficient therapy due to limited access to the expert healthcare services.


Our STTR Phase II project successfully transfers our recent laboratory research to practical clinical application and delivers costwise robot-assisted technologies and forearm training solutions to stroke survivors. For those people, our developed portable forearm rehabilitation robot will bring convenient and cost-effective robot-assisted physical therapy to post-stroke patient’s home and extend rehabilitation care beyond the hospital. Clinicians can also monitor the patient home-training results remotely for periodic evaluations and update guidance so that physical therapist loads and cost could be potentially reduce with this solution. The developed portable and low-cost device makes frequent and intensive treatment accessible to patients at home and can potentially have broad impact to rehabilitation of stroke and other neurological impairments. Moreover our project outcomes provide further advanced knowledge in science and clinic. Based on the accurate measurement of the biomechanical properties, the clinical researcher is able to evaluate the pathological changes and monitor progression of the rehabilitation quantitatively. The innovative stretching has been developed to insure safe and effective treatment of robot-assisted intervention and it is useful in other applications dealing with human-machine interface as well. Our development outcomes also provide practical solutions to the societal needs – the increasing number of stroke survivors and elderly people and the strong need for the corresponding health care system - by providing robotic therapists to individuals with neurological impairment. More people can potentially receive better costwise healthcare services from our developed technology. Although Tele-rehabilitation robots are not well recognized in the market now, our successful launching of the developed outcomes will help open the market and bring the benefits of more accessible therapy and outcome evaluations to the nation.
